ARTICLE.TITLE: Wednesday's Child: Teen in foster care for most of his life ready for adoptive family
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Wednesday's Child: Teen in foster care for most of his life ready for adoptive family

Governor Beshear recently proposed adding 350 new social workers to boost Kentucky’s child welfare system. Current state employees hope the move will help kids who have been stuck in the system for years. One of those children is 15-year-old Trenton. “When I was little I was abused and I was neglected, which the people came and got me out of my home,” Trenton said.It’s interesting what memories stick in our minds, while others seem to stay locked away with no key.Trenton is like many others in Kentucky’s child welfare system: in and out of foster homes and residential facilities for as long as he can remember. Trenton lives at The Life Connection in Senora, Kentucky. He said he’s learned tools to help him deal with past trauma. And now he’s ready for commitment.“Basically a family that would love me and keep on trying and trying and trying,” he said. "Just as long as I have a home, I just feel like I’m ready for a home. I’m loving, I love to play video games, like to fish, pretty energetic, I’m nice, I can get a long with people easily.”There is one more thing Trenton remembers from his early childhood. And it led to why he wants to be a police officer when he grows up.“When I was little my dad told me about his brother and told me some stories about how he helped the community, and I thought about that and chose I want to be a police officer,” he said.If you want to learn more about Trenton or other children waiting for forever homes, email christina.mora@hearst.com

Governor Beshear recently proposed adding 350 new social workers to boost Kentucky’s child welfare system. Current state employees hope the move will help kids who have been stuck in the system for years. One of those children is 15-year-old Trenton.

“When I was little I was abused and I was neglected, which the people came and got me out of my home,” Trenton said.



Advertisement

It’s interesting what memories stick in our minds, while others seem to stay locked away with no key.

Trenton is like many others in Kentucky’s child welfare system: in and out of foster homes and residential facilities for as long as he can remember.

Trenton lives at The Life Connection in Senora, Kentucky. He said he’s learned tools to help him deal with past trauma. And now he’s ready for commitment.

“Basically a family that would love me and keep on trying and trying and trying,” he said. "Just as long as I have a home, I just feel like I’m ready for a home. I’m loving, I love to play video games, like to fish, pretty energetic, I’m nice, I can get a long with people easily.”



There is one more thing Trenton remembers from his early childhood. And it led to why he wants to be a police officer when he grows up.

“When I was little my dad told me about his brother and told me some stories about how he helped the community, and I thought about that and chose I want to be a police officer,” he said.

If you want to learn more about Trenton or other children waiting for forever homes, email christina.mora@hearst.com
